htmlEmbed:
Facebook Finally Agrees to Eliminate Tool That Enabled Discriminatory Advertising@propublica12/31/2024

Six years after ProPublica revealed that Facebook allowed advertisers to exclude Black users and others, the company agreed to a settlement with the Justice Department to overhaul its ad algorithm system.

ArchivedRead

    <h1 class="opener__hed " >        Facebook Finally Agrees to Eliminate Tool That Enabled Discriminatory Advertising
    </h1>

    <h2 class="opener__dek "  >        Six years after ProPublica revealed that Facebook allowed advertisers to exclude Black users and others, the company agreed to a settlement with the Justice Department to overhaul its ad algorithm system.
    </h2>

                    <div class="article-body__top-notes" data-pp-location="top-note">
                

                                                
            <div class="article-body__note article-body__note--newsletter" id="newsletter-txt-note">
                <p>ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. Sign up to receive <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/the-big-story?source=www.propublica.org&placement=top-note&region=national">our biggest stories</a> as soon as theyâ€™re published.</p>

            </div>

                

            </div><!-- end .article-body__top-notes -->
        
        
        




                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="1.0">In a settlement <a href="https://www.justice.gov/opa/press-release/file/1514031/download?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery">announced</a> by the Department of Justice on Tuesday, Meta Platforms â€”Â formerly known as Facebook â€” has agreed to eliminate features in its advertising business that allow landlords, employers and credit agencies to discriminate against groups of people protected by federal civil rights laws.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.0">The deal comes nearly six years after ProPublica first <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-lets-advertisers-exclude-users-by-race">revealed</a> that Facebook let housing marketers exclude African Americans and others from seeing some of their advertisements. Federal law prohibits housing, employment and credit discrimination based on race, religion, gender, family status and disability.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="3.0"><a href="https://twitter.com/JuliaAngwin/status/1539639996474200067">For years</a>, ProPublica and other researchers showed that problems persisted in the delivery of advertisements related to housing, employment and credit, even as Facebook pledged to fix the loopholes that we identified.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.0">This weekâ€™s settlement was the result of a lawsuit brought three years ago by the Trump administration alleging that Metaâ€™s ad targeting system violated the Fair Housing Act. The DOJ also argued that Facebook used a machine learning algorithm to restrict and create ad audiences, which had the effect of skewing delivery toward or against legally protected groups. This was the first time the federal government challenged algorithmic bias under the Fair Housing Act.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="5.0">As part of the settlement, Meta has agreed to deploy new advertising methods that will be vetted by a third-party reviewer and overseen by the court.</p>
        
    
                        <aside class="bb-ad full | hide-print">
        <div class="htlad-inline-2"></div>
    </aside>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="7.0">The company said in a <a href="https://about.fb.com/news/2022/06/expanding-our-work-on-ads-fairness/">statement</a> that it will implement a â€œnovel use of machine learning technology that will work to ensure the age, gender and estimated race or ethnicity of a housing adâ€™s overall audience matches the age, gender, and estimated race or ethnicity mix of the population eligible to see that ad.â€</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="8.0">The statement, by Roy L. Austin Jr., Metaâ€™s vice president of civil rights and deputy general counsel, noted that although the settlement only requires Facebook to use its new tool for advertisements related to housing, it will also apply to posts about employment and credit. (Facebook declined a request for additional comment.)</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="9.0">Civil rights attorney Peter Romer-Friedman, who has brought several cases against the company, said that previous negotiations had tried and failed to hold Facebook accountable for algorithmic bias. â€œUltimately what this shows is that itâ€™s never been a question of feasibility to eliminate algorithmic bias,â€ he told ProPublica. â€œItâ€™s a question of will.â€</p>
        
    
                    
            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="11.0">After we <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-lets-advertisers-exclude-users-by-race">reported</a> on the potential for advertising discrimination in 2016, Facebook <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-to-stop-allowing-some-advertisers-to-exclude-users-by-race">quickly promised</a> to set up a system to catch and review ads that discriminate illegally. A year later, ProPublica found that it was <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-advertising-discrimination-housing-race-sex-national-origin">still possible</a> to exclude groups such as African Americans, mothers of high school kids, people interested in wheelchair ramps and Muslims from seeing advertisements. It was also <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-enabled-advertisers-to-reach-jew-haters">possible to target ads</a> to people with an interest in anti-Semitism, including options such as â€œHow to burn Jewsâ€ and â€œHitler did nothing wrong.â€</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.0">We later found that companies were posting employment ads that <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-is-letting-job-advertisers-target-only-men">women</a> and <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-ads-age-discrimination-targeting">older workers</a> could not see. In March 2019, Facebook <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-ads-discrimination-settlement-housing-employment-credit">settled a lawsuit</a> brought by civil rights groups by creating a â€œspecial ads portalâ€ specifically for employment, housing and credit ads. The company said the portal would curb advertisersâ€™ targeting options and also limit its algorithm from considering gender and race when deciding who should see ads.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="13.0">But when ProPublica worked with researchers <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1912.07579.pdf">at Northeastern University and Upturn</a> to test Facebookâ€™s new system, <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-ads-can-still-discriminate-against-women-and-older-workers-despite-a-civil-rights-settlement">we found</a> more examples of biased ad delivery. Though Facebookâ€™s modified algorithm prevented advertisers from explicit discrimination, delivery could still rely on â€œspecial adâ€ or â€œlookalikeâ€ proxy characteristics that correlated with race or gender.</p>
        
    
                        <aside class="bb-ad full | hide-print">
        <div class="htlad-inline-2"></div>
    </aside>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="15.0">The research also found that Facebook skewed the audience depending on the content of the ad itself. How many women might see a job listing for an open janitorial position, for instance, depended not just on what the advertiser told Facebook, but also on how Facebook interpreted the advertisementâ€™s image and text.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="16.0">ProPublica also continued to find employment advertisements that favored men or excluded older possible applicants, potentially violating <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/employers-used-facebook-to-keep-women-and-older-workers-from-seeing-job-ads-the-federal-government-thinks-thats-illegal">civil rights law</a>. Some advertisers we interviewed were surprised to learn that they were unable to reach a diverse audience, even if they tried.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="18.0">In a <a href="https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-secures-groundbreaking-settlement-agreement-meta-platforms-formerly-known">press release</a>, the DOJ said Tuesdayâ€™s settlement requires Meta to stop using the â€œSpecial Ad Audienceâ€ tool by the end of the year. It also requires Meta to change its algorithm â€œto address disparities for race, ethnicity and sex between advertisersâ€™ targeted audiences and the group of Facebook users to whom Facebookâ€™s personalization algorithms actually deliver the ads.â€ The company must share details with the DOJ and an independent reviewer before implementing changes.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="19.0">As part of the settlement, Meta also agreed to pay a $115,054 fee, the maximum allowed by the law.</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="20.0">â€œBecause of this ground-breaking lawsuit, Meta will â€” for the first time â€” change its ad delivery system to address algorithmic discrimination,â€ U.S. Attorney Damian Williams for the Southern District of New York said in a statement. â€œBut if Meta fails to demonstrate that it has sufficiently changed its delivery system to guard against algorithmic bias, this office will proceed with the litigation.â€</p>

                            </a>

            by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/renee-dudley">Renee Dudley</a>, with research by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/doris-burke">Doris Burke</a>,             <time class="timestamp" datetime="2024-11-15EST06:00">Nov. 15, 6 a.m. EST</time>

        <h3 class="story-card__hed" >
            <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/facebook-instagram-meta-deceptive-political-ads-election">
                                    Exploiting Metaâ€™s Weaknesses, Deceptive Political Ads Thrived on Facebook and Instagram in Run-Up to Election
                            </a>
        </h3>

        <p class="story-card__dek" >
                            Despite Meta's stated commitment to crack down on harmful content, it failed to catch tens of thousands of ads that used false claims and deepfakes of political figures to collect usersâ€™ sensitive personal data or bait them into monthly charges.

readabilityObject.title: Facebook Finally Agrees to Eliminate Tool That Enabled Discriminatory Advertising
readabilityObject.content:
In a settlement announced by the Department of Justice on Tuesday, Meta Platforms â€” formerly known as Facebook â€” has agreed to eliminate features in its advertising business that allow landlords, employers and credit agencies to discriminate against groups of people protected by federal civil rights laws.

The deal comes nearly six years after ProPublica first revealed that Facebook let housing marketers exclude African Americans and others from seeing some of their advertisements. Federal law prohibits housing, employment and credit discrimination based on race, religion, gender, family status and disability.

For years, ProPublica and other researchers showed that problems persisted in the delivery of advertisements related to housing, employment and credit, even as Facebook pledged to fix the loopholes that we identified.

This weekâ€™s settlement was the result of a lawsuit brought three years ago by the Trump administration alleging that Metaâ€™s ad targeting system violated the Fair Housing Act. The DOJ also argued that Facebook used a machine learning algorithm to restrict and create ad audiences, which had the effect of skewing delivery toward or against legally protected groups. This was the first time the federal government challenged algorithmic bias under the Fair Housing Act.

As part of the settlement, Meta has agreed to deploy new advertising methods that will be vetted by a third-party reviewer and overseen by the court.

The company said in a statement that it will implement a â€œnovel use of machine learning technology that will work to ensure the age, gender and estimated race or ethnicity of a housing adâ€™s overall audience matches the age, gender, and estimated race or ethnicity mix of the population eligible to see that ad.â€

The statement, by Roy L. Austin Jr., Metaâ€™s vice president of civil rights and deputy general counsel, noted that although the settlement only requires Facebook to use its new tool for advertisements related to housing, it will also apply to posts about employment and credit. (Facebook declined a request for additional comment.)

Civil rights attorney Peter Romer-Friedman, who has brought several cases against the company, said that previous negotiations had tried and failed to hold Facebook accountable for algorithmic bias. â€œUltimately what this shows is that itâ€™s never been a question of feasibility to eliminate algorithmic bias,â€ he told ProPublica. â€œItâ€™s a question of will.â€

After we reported on the potential for advertising discrimination in 2016, Facebook quickly promised to set up a system to catch and review ads that discriminate illegally. A year later, ProPublica found that it was still possible to exclude groups such as African Americans, mothers of high school kids, people interested in wheelchair ramps and Muslims from seeing advertisements. It was also possible to target ads to people with an interest in anti-Semitism, including options such as â€œHow to burn Jewsâ€ and â€œHitler did nothing wrong.â€

We later found that companies were posting employment ads that women and older workers could not see. In March 2019, Facebook settled a lawsuit brought by civil rights groups by creating a â€œspecial ads portalâ€ specifically for employment, housing and credit ads. The company said the portal would curb advertisersâ€™ targeting options and also limit its algorithm from considering gender and race when deciding who should see ads.

But when ProPublica worked with researchers at Northeastern University and Upturn to test Facebookâ€™s new system, we found more examples of biased ad delivery. Though Facebookâ€™s modified algorithm prevented advertisers from explicit discrimination, delivery could still rely on â€œspecial adâ€ or â€œlookalikeâ€ proxy characteristics that correlated with race or gender.

The research also found that Facebook skewed the audience depending on the content of the ad itself. How many women might see a job listing for an open janitorial position, for instance, depended not just on what the advertiser told Facebook, but also on how Facebook interpreted the advertisementâ€™s image and text.

ProPublica also continued to find employment advertisements that favored men or excluded older possible applicants, potentially violating civil rights law. Some advertisers we interviewed were surprised to learn that they were unable to reach a diverse audience, even if they tried.

In a press release, the DOJ said Tuesdayâ€™s settlement requires Meta to stop using the â€œSpecial Ad Audienceâ€ tool by the end of the year. It also requires Meta to change its algorithm â€œto address disparities for race, ethnicity and sex between advertisersâ€™ targeted audiences and the group of Facebook users to whom Facebookâ€™s personalization algorithms actually deliver the ads.â€ The company must share details with the DOJ and an independent reviewer before implementing changes.

As part of the settlement, Meta also agreed to pay a $115,054 fee, the maximum allowed by the law.

â€œBecause of this ground-breaking lawsuit, Meta will â€” for the first time â€” change its ad delivery system to address algorithmic discrimination,â€ U.S. Attorney Damian Williams for the Southern District of New York said in a statement. â€œBut if Meta fails to demonstrate that it has sufficiently changed its delivery system to guard against algorithmic bias, this office will proceed with the litigation.â€
